SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the reader:

Generalizing this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about any blank spaces. If there are questions for which you have no answers, don't worry about them. You may be able to answer them later.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days Past," and Western Canadian Pioneer Estate is still being circulated. If you have not already answered these, we would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Encapsulation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Branch Office at the University of Saskatchewan and sent to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Rakalton, Sask.

Please send your completed questionnaires to:

A word of explanation to the reader:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experience as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may serve as a basis for your answers.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada between 1875 and 1925. If there is more than one person in your family who lived during this period, please complete separate questionnaires for each member of the family.

If more than one member of the family lives in the same province or not, write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Arborfield, 1897

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure about the name or you have (given it), please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your instruction, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: JAMES DAVIDSON, TULLOCH
2. Your address: ARBORFIELD, DASKAIS
3. Date: ...........................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): HOLLAND ISLANDS, SCOTLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? PETER TULLOCH, JUNIOR
6. When did you come to Canada? (Give month and year): NOVEMBER 1897
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to BRANTFORD, ONTARIO
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (answered by Mr. Davidson)

Mr. Davidson has been very kind in answering my questions. He has been very helpful and has given me many interesting stories about his experiences in the early days of Brantford. I am grateful to him for taking the time to share his memories with me.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? My friends and my relatives had no say in the decision.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

I travelled by myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use to travel?

The farm I left to go to school was in Ontario, so I took a train to Toronto, then a boat to Quebec City, and finally a train to Montreal.

14. What incidents of the journey most do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

I remember seeing Indians sometimes. They came to see us and we gave them food. We also saw some animals along the way.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Saskatoon I worked at a sawmill and then moved to Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On the Wascana District.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I have lived in Regina since 1911 and in 1912 I bought two acres of farmland near Regina.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked on farms in Scotland for four years. I was raised on a small farm in the Athabasca Valley. I worked as a team hand out on a ranch in Alberta. I then went to work for the federal government breaking land at Fort Macleod and then worked for the Canadian Pacific Railway in Calgary. I then moved to Regina to work for the Saskatchewan Wheat Pool.

I now own a small farm in the Athabasca Valley. I am retired and enjoy spending time with my family.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? My friends and my relatives had no way in their hearts of let William when I was uncertain of my future or my mother.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, etc.)?

13. What means of transportation did you use to travel?

The farm hall to the town of Winnipeg then by train to Brandon. Then back to each town, one by bus, another by car.

14. How did you feel about the journey? What was the most memorable part of your trip?

I traveled by myself by bus from Brandon to Winnipeg.

15. What did you see along the way? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

I remember seeing Indians sometimes before we saw the prairie land.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On the Wabana District.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I have lived mostly here in Okotoks since 1911 and one in 1912.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked on farms in Alberta for four years.

I worked on a small farm in the Athabasca Valley.

I worked at the Canadian Pacific Railway as a team hand out of Calgary until 1910. Then I worked as a team hand at the Canadian Pacific Railway in Calgary until 1912.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, how many?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

25. What other reasons were there?
25. When was the first car used in the community? The first car at Holman, 1907.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes it?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? At Holman, 100 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) Holman, 34 miles; Eldersley, 92 miles; then Okotoks, 18 miles; then Okotoks, 18 miles.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? At Holman, 100 miles; then Okotoks, 34 miles; then Eldersley, 92 miles; then Okotoks, 18 miles.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1940 at Okotoks.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? We would have instructed the local store owner to buy them for us.

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.

In the first year of the mail-order business, the mail-order catalogue was not very popular because we had no money to pay for the catalogue.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Bell Telephone.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
25. When was the first car used in the community? The first car at Tulloch 1907

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes of vehicle did you own?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? At Tulloch 100 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? At Tulloch 1907

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1940 at Eskerfield

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.

For the first year of the Century the mail order business started. This was more because we did not have them near us. We had the Country store owner buy them for us. We would take advantage of the special prices he could get by ordering in bulk.

32. When did you first have a telephone call what company provided it? Bell Telephone

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make the decision? We came here to try our luck and see how things would turn out. We found that even though we were very well known in the area where we came from, we could not find work here. We decided to stay and see what we could do.
36. If you or some members of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any charitable or religious mission, list them, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were veterans, list them, giving dates wherever possible.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, hills, etc.) Try to get (1) an exception, (2) suggestions, (3) reasons, (4) any changes in names since the first mention, (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new names above in (1), (2), (3).

The place name was given a descriptive name by a man who lived there named Mr. Smith.

This book has been donated to the Tulloch James Davidson Foundation.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live, and occupations.

Margaret Tulloch, my daughter, lives on the farm.

James Tulloch, my son, lives on the farm.

He owns no land.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Roads are built instead of trails. Railroads

Hundreds of miles have been built since farms to transport

Cars driven by gas have been replaced by threshing machines.

Hospital and school buildings have been constructed.

The clearing of the prairie has been completed.

Research laboratories and the development of the Extension Department

of the University of Saskatchewan are being expanded.
